# News comment title:
Joe Biden Smiles, Laughs, and Mostly Kicks Ass

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Biden answered the "tone" question first, and did the same thing.  For the record, I was bothered by both.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Biden's demeanor was only "spooky" to the abnormal.

Biden has a warm personality and smile.  That he smiled (I heard no laughs) was an obvious criticism of Ryan's lying.  

By now Biden doesn't need coaching: he's been debating for decades.  Ryan?  He needs to stop the fake-sincere hangdog look, the lying, and fake religiosity.

Some have said Biden "smirked".  Didn't happen.  Republicans have the monopoly on that, as it does on the bootstrap industry.

But, being a wingnut, we know what you're comments are worth:

NOTHING.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The debate roundup reminds me of the Harlem Globetrotters beating some no name team and people complaining they were too flashy.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Defense Attorneys Plan to Fight NSA Evidence in Drug Cases

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
When I said all this terror war bullshit would get turned around on us people called me a crazy asshole.

Now the DEA buys your personal info from NSA, sells that to the feds and the locals, and they use that illegal surveillance to build a secret drug case against you using every facet of the post 9/11 gravy train infrastructure we paid for because we wanted to be safe.

welcome to the new reality.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
When I said all this terror war bullshit would get turned around on us people called me a crazy asshole.

Now the DEA buys your personal info from NSA, sells that to the feds and the locals, and they use that illegal surveillance to build a secret drug case against you using every facet of the post 9/11 gravy train infrastructure we paid for because we wanted to be safe.

welcome to the new reality.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


What about the fruit of the poisonous tree? If the NSA didn't get a warrant, then everything that came from it should be thrown out, even if the court knew about it. And all those participating in this scheme are guilty of a criminal conspiracy to deny these defendants their civil rights.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
When I said all this terror war bullshit would get turned around on us people called me a crazy asshole.

Now the DEA buys your personal info from NSA, sells that to the feds and the locals, and they use that illegal surveillance to build a secret drug case against you using every facet of the post 9/11 gravy train infrastructure we paid for because we wanted to be safe.

welcome to the new reality.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):

Now the DEA buys your personal info from NSA, sells that to the feds and the locals, and they use that illegal surveillance to build a secret drug case against you using every facet of the post 9/11 gravy train infrastructure we paid for because we wanted to be safe.

welcome to the new reality.

If the tips were not obtained in violation of the Constitution, then there would be no need for the secrecy. A wiretap by court order would not be questioned. But what is happening here, apparently, is the wholesale capture of phone calls and emails. The SOD isn't running a system of informants that need protection, they are running a general search on the entire country. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Spy Camp: Photos From East Germany's Secret Intelligence Files

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It is foolhardy to think for even one second the NSA is not the Stasi or even close. The NSA and the government it represents is 100x worse than the Stasi , They will not be satisfied with just knowing every thought and movement of the US population, they want the world .....................On the plus side the NSA and DHS are going to face the same fate if not worse than the Stasi agents did after the wall fell..............................we will hunt them down like the Jews hunt Nazis and only the most lucky amongst them will survive to reach a trial.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
oh, you are just making up stuff here and not likely to be taken seriously. Why dramatize something, making it sound like a B movie when the truth is enough as it is?


No the NSA isn't worse than the Stasi. No it is not 100 times worse than the Stasi. And it is even less sensible to make threats like you did against the NSA. You say you are sick of the stupid, and then make statements that give evidence to the contrary, you seem to embrace it.


Should we be outraged about the erosion of our 4th Amendment rights? YES! Should we demand the spying on any citizen without probable cause stop? YES! Should we be able to use our phones, emails, cell phones, and do internet searches in privacy? YES! If we don't do something to stop what is happening now, do we need to worry about the likelihood that we COULD end up with something as bad as the Stasi? Probably, YES!


You don't have to use hyperbole. Just stick with the facts, people need to hear them. You spouting off all of the silly stuff just makes you sound like a crank and the entire message will get lost.


The NSA does not have to be 100 times worse than the Stasi for me to know I don't want unchecked invasion of my private life. It doesn't have to be that for me to know I don't want them capturing my cell phone calls or any of the other things that has been happening. Stick with factual things, leave the extra drama behind. And nobody asked me if I wanted billions spent on housing of our personal data, you could write about that. If terrorism is the issue, probable cause would solve that question and if it is proven there is nothing to worry about, that information ought not be stored, it should be deleted or destroyed.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Cheney.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
If You Think the NSA Debate Has Been Valuable, You Have Edward Snowden to Thank

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
>>I wouldn't defend every last thing Snowden has done.

Uhhhhh.... YEAH. He took a job where he not only violated the rules of his workplace, he got others to do so as well (by getting them to give him their passwords so he could access additional data).

I'll repeat that as the additional information about the NSA's activities has leaked out my attitudes around Snowden have changed, and mainly for the positive, but that's partly because they started off so negative. The original "shocking revelations" about the metadata gathering activities were all known to me (at least in the broad) and Snowden seemed like a grandstander (that he was aligned with one-note pony Glenn Greenwald didn't help). But the drip-drip-drip has shown the programs are more extensive than (I would guess) anyone realized, and bringing this to light has done a real public service. That DOES NOT make Snowden a "Whistle Blower" (in the legal sense of the term) but probably makes him the equivalent of a "whistle blower" in the functional sense. 

Over and above the good which has come out of Snowden's revelations (and yes, on balance I think this has been a Good Thing™) there would almost certainly be real social value in Snowden coming back, facing charges, and making his case to the public. Unfortunately, his situation is complicated enough that the outcome would be far from certain, so it's unlikely this will happen and Snowden will remain a powerful Rohrschach test for peoples' complex attitudes about the trade-off between security and privacy.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yes. And in the process doing more than you or I or 10,000 protesters will ever do to protect the individual freedom and democracy of the citizens of the united states, and the hundreds of millions of people in allied nations.  Or would you rather we all slide into having our own versions of the Stasi monitoring us?

Snowden is a hero.  Most of the time, such people are a-holes on close examination. A "nice person" is much less likely to have the nads to actually take such actions.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


In Germany or Brazil he stands a good chance of being murdered by CIA jackals. He's safer where he is until we have a government not owned by the intelligence agencies.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
If You Think the NSA Debate Has Been Valuable, You Have Edward Snowden to Thank

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
>>I wouldn't defend every last thing Snowden has done.

Uhhhhh.... YEAH. He took a job where he not only violated the rules of his workplace, he got others to do so as well (by getting them to give him their passwords so he could access additional data).

I'll repeat that as the additional information about the NSA's activities has leaked out my attitudes around Snowden have changed, and mainly for the positive, but that's partly because they started off so negative. The original "shocking revelations" about the metadata gathering activities were all known to me (at least in the broad) and Snowden seemed like a grandstander (that he was aligned with one-note pony Glenn Greenwald didn't help). But the drip-drip-drip has shown the programs are more extensive than (I would guess) anyone realized, and bringing this to light has done a real public service. That DOES NOT make Snowden a "Whistle Blower" (in the legal sense of the term) but probably makes him the equivalent of a "whistle blower" in the functional sense. 

Over and above the good which has come out of Snowden's revelations (and yes, on balance I think this has been a Good Thing™) there would almost certainly be real social value in Snowden coming back, facing charges, and making his case to the public. Unfortunately, his situation is complicated enough that the outcome would be far from certain, so it's unlikely this will happen and Snowden will remain a powerful Rohrschach test for peoples' complex attitudes about the trade-off between security and privacy.

# News comment title:
If You Think the NSA Debate Has Been Valuable, You Have Edward Snowden to Thank

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
>>I wouldn't defend every last thing Snowden has done.

Uhhhhh.... YEAH. He took a job where he not only violated the rules of his workplace, he got others to do so as well (by getting them to give him their passwords so he could access additional data).

I'll repeat that as the additional information about the NSA's activities has leaked out my attitudes around Snowden have changed, and mainly for the positive, but that's partly because they started off so negative. The original "shocking revelations" about the metadata gathering activities were all known to me (at least in the broad) and Snowden seemed like a grandstander (that he was aligned with one-note pony Glenn Greenwald didn't help). But the drip-drip-drip has shown the programs are more extensive than (I would guess) anyone realized, and bringing this to light has done a real public service. That DOES NOT make Snowden a "Whistle Blower" (in the legal sense of the term) but probably makes him the equivalent of a "whistle blower" in the functional sense. 

Over and above the good which has come out of Snowden's revelations (and yes, on balance I think this has been a Good Thing™) there would almost certainly be real social value in Snowden coming back, facing charges, and making his case to the public. Unfortunately, his situation is complicated enough that the outcome would be far from certain, so it's unlikely this will happen and Snowden will remain a powerful Rohrschach test for peoples' complex attitudes about the trade-off between security and privacy.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yes. And in the process doing more than you or I or 10,000 protesters will ever do to protect the individual freedom and democracy of the citizens of the united states, and the hundreds of millions of people in allied nations.  Or would you rather we all slide into having our own versions of the Stasi monitoring us?

Snowden is a hero.  Most of the time, such people are a-holes on close examination. A "nice person" is much less likely to have the nads to actually take such actions.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


"I think Obama has done a better job with transparency than any president in my lifetime."


Ah well...goodbye.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Why Silicon Valley's Top Dogs Fought Back So Feebly Against NSA Spying

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Here is a look at Apple's latest data breakdown showing exactly how many times the company was asked to release users private data for American users:

http://viableopposition.blogspot.ca/2014/01/apple-government-snooping-and-your.html

Ah, the fleeting illusion of privacy, even in the hands of what was once a counter-culture corporation.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Hey Josh, this is Adi Kamdar from EFF—I tried to make this clear when we spoke, and I'm surprised you only decided to use that one quote to fit the angle of this piece, but the SOPA vs. Day We Fight Back success comparison is flawed: they were two separate asks on two separate topics set in two very separate moments.

The fight against mass surveillance is a longer term project, but what we saw yesterday during the Day We Fight Back was stunning. Over 85,000 calls and 180,000 emails—as well as over 200,000 international signatures—is remarkable. And companies did in fact get involved: Google sent an email to over 3 million people to get them to take action in addition to writing a blog post; Facebook, Twitter, Microsoft, and Reddit posted, not to mention pushed the Reform Government Surveillance action that converted to thousands taking action; Mozilla changed the startpage on millions of people's browsers—the list (Tumblr, DuckDuckGo, Namecheap, etc.) goes on.

The SOPA fight was a long, long fight. The blackout day wasn't the only event—there were major days of action for months leading up to it, including American Censorship Day (http://americancensorship.org/). We didn't call for a blackout, so why would websites black their homepages out or go offline? Comparing what happened yesterday with single biggest online activist moment ever is absurd. 

Yesterday, we made an impact, and we laid the foundation for an escalating campaign. From a specific perspective, it was a Senate-facing act, and I'd ask any Senate office if they've received such volume of calls recently. The "we" in the Day We Fight Back *was* huge, the crowd speaking out is only getting bigger, and we definitely accomplished our goals.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The numbers are actually small, which probably reflects the NSA's ability to tap the optic cables and take everything.

# News comment title:
The Silliest Snowden Theory Yet

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"Which brings me to Economist editor Edward Lucas and the most ridiculous thing I've ever read, his short new ebook, The Snowden Operation: Inside the West's Greatest Intelligence Disaster".


While I have NO doubt that the ebook is filled with ridiculous claims, I think if this is the worst one has read....in the batshit crazy world, I would consider myself lucky. Every time I read something that some crazy person has claimed, I think it can't get worse than this.....and so far, I have been wrong every time.


One important thing we should remember is, that even IF the Russians had any part in what Snowden released, there would have been no story at all, had members of our government not violated our rights by spying on us with no probable cause. There is just no way I am going to believe we have that many terrorists who lead ordinary lives and car pool their kids from school to soccer fields and need spying. The issue they are trying to raise about the Russian involvement I feel is only a distraction from the fact that our government has overstepped their duties. 


And at this point, I don't care what the Russians may have offered Snowden (I see no evidence they did much other than let him stay). I think we need to do something about the 'enemy within".


I argued with military friends in 1980 that the Russians were going to rot from within, from corruption and poverty. I also said that once we didn't have the Cold War, our government would turn their spying skills on the US citizens. I was called 'radical' by some of those old friends, but this is what happened.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The enemy within is far worse than any outside enemy. And, in fact, it appears to have taken over the government and is now running things from the shadows. Obama, in particular, appears to be a puppet, and has been from his first day in office.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Silliest Snowden Theory Yet

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"Which brings me to Economist editor Edward Lucas and the most ridiculous thing I've ever read, his short new ebook, The Snowden Operation: Inside the West's Greatest Intelligence Disaster".


While I have NO doubt that the ebook is filled with ridiculous claims, I think if this is the worst one has read....in the batshit crazy world, I would consider myself lucky. Every time I read something that some crazy person has claimed, I think it can't get worse than this.....and so far, I have been wrong every time.


One important thing we should remember is, that even IF the Russians had any part in what Snowden released, there would have been no story at all, had members of our government not violated our rights by spying on us with no probable cause. There is just no way I am going to believe we have that many terrorists who lead ordinary lives and car pool their kids from school to soccer fields and need spying. The issue they are trying to raise about the Russian involvement I feel is only a distraction from the fact that our government has overstepped their duties. 


And at this point, I don't care what the Russians may have offered Snowden (I see no evidence they did much other than let him stay). I think we need to do something about the 'enemy within".


I argued with military friends in 1980 that the Russians were going to rot from within, from corruption and poverty. I also said that once we didn't have the Cold War, our government would turn their spying skills on the US citizens. I was called 'radical' by some of those old friends, but this is what happened.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


One wouldn't expect Obama to be so much like a  Cheney neocon that Bill Kristol--a Cheney admirer--congratulated him on becoming a "born-again neocon" by his second year in office. That wouldn't happen without a good dose of NSA blackmail.

>>> END COMMENT <<<
